doc.title: Italy M&A, Africa Q Wrap, Iliad results, Altice results
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Telco Daily Italy MA Africa 2Q Wrap Iliad results Altice resultsTelco Daily Italy MA Africa 2Q Wrap Iliad results Altice_2025-08-29

passages.text: We highlight latest research, news flow and significant observations relevant to our stock coverage across European/CEEMEA Telecoms, and Global Towers/Satellites.
Italy M&A - Consolidation postponed
Telco conference 2 and 3 September - Please see below link for registration details
African Telcos 2Q Wrap - Solid Growth, Nigeria Accelerates
Iliad (NC) - Drops Italian tie- up plan; domestic consolidation being discussed
Altice (NC) - France remains under pressure, Portugal holding up despite Digi entry

Barclays Media and Telecom Forum 2025 (Virtual)Registration is now open for our Media and Telecom Forum taking place virtually on 2 and 3 September. The forum will offer the opportunity to attend virtual meetings and fireside chats with senior management from a wide range of global media and telecom companies. Please see the link for registration details.

At its 2Q25 results press conference, the CEO of Iliad (Not Covered), Thomas Reynaud, confirmed that while the group remains open to domestic consolidation opportunities, it will not pursue further discussions with Telecom Italia to consolidate the Italian market. Reynaud stated that no talks have taken place since early April and none are expected to resume. He emphasized that consolidation prospects with Telecom Italia are now considered closed, and the prevailing assumption is a continuation of a four- operator market in Italy. We do not believe this means consolidation will not eventually happen in Italy but clearly it is unlikely in the short term. As shown in Fig 1, no player is earning its cost of capital in Italy with an average ROCE of \(1.2\%\) Whilst competition has slightly abated, we do not see for most players a path to earn an attractive return. Consolidation would create material value for all players. There are other potential combinations besides Iliad/TI and also the ability to consider infrastructure deals,
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 4. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 07:06 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 07:07 GMT Restricted - External

notably on mobile as discussed in Consolidation 2.0 - Sizing the RanCo opportunity - 26 June 2025. Whilst Iliad management has consistently indicated over the years that its 'Plan A' for Italy was organic growth, it has made three bids in Italy to pursue consolidation over the past few years.

We believe the African Telcos are benefiting from solid growth levers in most markets - with South Africa the only real exception. Data usage continues to grow across the markets, and with growing smartphone penetration we see stronger demand in coming years. In 1H25, MTN reported \(+22.4\%\) yoy service revenue growth (organic, constant FX) (1H24: \(+12.1\%\) ), while Airtel Africa revenue grew \(+24.9\%\) yoy in 1Q26 (4Q25: \(23.2\%\) ). Vodacom posted \(+13.8\%\) in 1Q26 (4Q25: \(+13.5\%\) ). South Africa's competitive landscape is challenging, and we expect service revenue growth to remain modest for the remainder of the year. In contrast, Nigeria's recent price increases have been well received, and we expect this to support stronger revenue growth in the second half. Mobile money continues to be a key growth engine for both MTN and Airtel Africa. Despite some delays in monetization, the segment is showing healthy expansion, partly driven by rising smartphone adoption. With ongoing investments in distribution and fintech use cases, we are positive on the outlook for mobile money through the rest of the year.

As discussed above, Iliad CEO Thomas Reynaud has indicated that the company would not pursue further discussions with Telecom Italia. Management however flagged that Iliad had balance sheet flexibility for any potential deal, either for geographic expansion or consolidation. On that note, as for other French operators, Iliad's management confirmed that discussions about consolidation in France had taken place, although they were "very preliminary discussions" and a deal would be complex. As we discussed in French consolidation: Third time lucky? - 20 May 2025, in light of heightened competition and persistently low ROCEs in France, we see substantial potential for value creation through consolidation. During the results conference call, management also discussed operating trends, notably in France and Italy. Results showed a continued slowdown in France with service revenues up only \(+0.9\%\) yoy \((+4\%)\) in 1Q25) as volume growth stalled (no Mobile/Broadband growth) but management is confident it can continue to grow revenues and expects 2H to remain in positive territory. In Italy, service revenue growth remains solid at \(+9.4\%\) yoy (in line with 1Q25). Mobile volumes remained steady with \(+287k\) mobile net adds (vs \(+218k\) in 4Q25) and 32k Broadband net adds (vs \(+40k\) in 1Q25). Management also expects to continue to grow and does not see a need to change its strategy. Source: Company (28 August 2025)

Altice France revenue/EBITDA declined \(- 9.1\% / - 10.8\%\) y/y in 2Q25. Within divisions, residential service revenue declined \(- 9.1\%\) y/y including \(- 6.2\% / - 11.3\%\) decline in fixed and mobile respectively. Total pro- forma net debt stood at â‚¬15.8bn implying a leverage ratio of 5x on an LTM basis. A network outage had an impact on net adds during the quarter (- 21k/- 5k on residential mobile postpaid and fixed respectively). Residential fixed base and postpaid mobile declined - 17k (1Q25: - 3k/+17k). On consolidation the company indicated it was actively reviewing its portfolio and did not believe the current political turmoil in France would have an impact on the current business or ability to do transactions. In Portugal Altice revenue and EBITDA were \(+4.6\% / - 1.1\%\) y/y. Notably in fixed segment revenue improved \(+13\%\) y/y while mobile remained soft at \(- 6\%\) y/y. Altice Portugal had 6.6m addressable FTTH homes passed in total at the end of 2Q25, including 5.9m homes passed owned by FastFiber. Altice Portugal

added \(+4k\) fibre customers during the quarter and \(+33k\) customers in mobile postpaid segment. Prepaid segment remained under pressure with - 213k subscriber loss. Altice confirmed that it has received an offer for Mobile in Israel and it is reviewing the offer. Source: Company (28 August 2025)

German fibre - Vodafone freezes wholesale agreement with Deutsche GlasfaserAccording to WirtschaftsWoche (WiWo), Vodafone has notified its dealers of a temporary halt in marketing Deutsche Glasfaser products. While Deutsche Glasfaser maintains that its long- term marketing partnership with Vodafone remains intact, the two companies are currently engaged in negotiations over wholesale terms to better align with customer expectations. Vodafone has expressed concerns that Deutsche Glasfaser's pricing exceeds market averages, making it difficult to present compelling offers to consumers. Source: WiWo (28 August 2025)

VodafoneThree - Now offers broadband services on CommunityFibre networkVodafoneThree has now gone live on CommunityFibre's fibre network. The operator says this means that 550k "additional" homes can now access their broadband plans. Until now it's generally only been possible to take Vodafone's home broadband packages via Openreach or CityFibre's national full fibre networks. Vodafone states that the combination of Openreach, CityFibre and CommunityFibre implies that it can now offer broadband service to more than 21.5 million homes nationwide. Source: ISPReview (28 August 2025)

With Bayrou likely to go, we think Macron will appoint a new PM and try to muddle through, rather than call fresh elections or resign. So spike in risk premia likely largely over for now. EU political noise reinforces US leadership, already helped by Fed & Al, but don't write- off Europe just yet.

Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
